Snippet.Para: Taiwanese bakery chain famous for its Litchi Rose bread is likely to debut in Singapore next year and founder Wu already plans to spice up his buns with curry and durian

LeadPara.Para: Taiwanese bakery chain famous for its Litchi Rose bread is likely to debut in Singapore next year and founder Wu already plans to spice up his buns with curry and durian

The deal may not be officially inked yet, but key research and development chefs from BreadTalk Group in Singapore have already been picked to go to Taiwan for training at famed bakery chain Wu Pao Chun.

TailParas.Para: There has been plenty of buzz over the brand opening stores here, following news of BreadTalk Group's indirect wholly owned subsidiary, Shanghai Star Food F&B Management, entering a joint venture with Wu Pao Chun (WPC) Food .
It allows Shanghai Star to operate the Taiwanese bakery brand in Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Guangzhou in China.

The Shanghai branch is slated to open this year, says BreadTalk Group chief executive Henry Chu. Fans of WPC here will have to be more patient, however, as the brand is likely to debut in Singapore only next year, after the joint venture agreement has been signed.

In a telephone interview, The Sunday Times spoke to Wu Pao-chun, chef-founder of the eponymous eight-year-old Taiwanese brand known for its Asian-style soft buns, artisanal European-style bakes and Japanese bread.
WPC also sells Taiwan-style pineapple cakes, a selection of tea and jam, and Wu's cookbooks.

Born in Pingtung County in Taiwan, the youngest of eight children started out as a baking apprentice at age 17 in various bakeries, before getting the opportunity to participate in bread competitions at the age of 26.

I must have his famous Taiwan longan with red wine bread and the Taiwan Litchi Rose... I'm more than happy to queue for the bread in Taiwan and I'll be happy to do the same here. I just hope the standards are kept up.
HOUSEWIFE GERALDINE LIM, a fan of baker Wu Pao-chun (above). She buys his breads whenever she visits Taiwan
Calling it a "dream fulfilled", he won the title of Master Baker at the Masters de la Boulangerie, or Bakery Masters in Paris, in 2010, with his Taiwan Litchi Rose bread.
That same year, he opened his first store in Kaohsiung. This was followed in 2013 with one in Taipei. He opened his third store last year in Taichung.

The Taiwanese company sells 3,000 to 4,000 pieces of bread a day and most of them are European loaves. About 400 loaves each of Taiwan Litchi Rose and Taiwan longan with red wine bread are produced daily and these account for 20 per cent of the brand's revenue.
He also made news in 2013 for not getting into the Executive Master of Business Administration programme at the National Chengchi University and National Sun Yat-sen University in Taiwan.

He was accepted at the National University of Singapore instead. His stint gave him a better understanding of the scene here and his favourite local delights are Mao Shan Wang durians, Hainanese chicken rice, bak kut teh and kopi si with crispy kaya toast.

Helping to seal the deal to work with BreadTalk was Din Tai Fung chief executive Yang Jihua, who introduced Wu to the group about four years ago. BreadTalk Group runs the Din Tai Fung franchise in Singapore, Thailand and London.

Wu, 48, says: "I had no intention of expanding WPC overseas at that point. I was more concerned about stabilising my business. But we became more familiar with each other over the years. I have been approached by other parties to expand, but many were not in the bakery business, not even in food."

In line with the brand's championing of local produce, the father of four children - aged two months to 17 years - says he would like to use local ingredients here and expresses interest in using curry spices as well as durians.

The joint venture is a 80-20 split, for Shanghai and Singapore, with him holding the minority share. He says he has taken a more "conservative approach". He also adds that there is an option of increasing the share to 40 per cent for Beijing, Shenzhen and Guangzhou.
BreadTalk Group's Mr Chu, 48, says a location in Orchard Road would be ideal for "strong branding and good traffic".
"WPC will not open at the same rate as BreadTalk - we differentiate our brand and WPC very clearly."

He says of the bread scene here: "There is a lot of competition. Old brands are improving while new brands are coming in. WPC will differentiate from the rest as a premium brand. We also believe that its founder can help us to improve what we offer at BreadTalk."
WPC executive vice-chairman David Chiu, 59, uses Disneyland as an example.

"You have Disneyland all over the world and, in whichever country it is located, it speaks the local language and adapts to the scene there. No one questions its authenticity and it still showcases the Disneyland spirit. WPC will be like that - no matter where we open our stores, and even when we infuse local flavours into our bread, our bread culture will never change."
Those in the food scene who have tried WPC breads welcome the brand's entrance into Singapore and say that the high standards that it is known for in Taiwan will help to elevate the bread scene here.
Besides the usual big bakery chains, other notable names that have already peaked in popularity since they opened include Maison Kayser from France and the Duke Bakery chain from Taiwan.

Pine Garden's Cake's secondgeneration owner and managing director Wei Chan says: "Mr Wu has led a humble life and made a name for himself on a global scale. That deserves much respect. I hope he serves as an inspiring story to the younger generation of bakers here. I would be happy to welcome him to my store to tap his experience."
Chef Daniel Tay, founder of the Old Seng Choong confectionery and Cat & The Fiddle cheesecake brands, met Wu recently and holds WPC in high regard.

He says: "It is not just about the ingredients that are used, but also the fermentation techniques that are put in. He understands those techniques very well and that takes time - like wine that has to mature.
"I'm concerned only about how many people they can get to work here, because I noticed easily 40 people in his bakery. With the high cost of labour here, that might be difficult."

Mr Konstantino Blokbergen, founder of Firebake restaurant in East Coast Road, which sells wood-fired sourdough bread, says: "More variety - in terms of bread types available - makes the industry more interesting and is beneficial for consumers. WPC's entrance is good for competition, but I see a clear and separate market trend focused on artisanship and I believe it may be targeting a different, more mainstream crowd."
A fan of WPC's breads is housewife Geraldine Lim, 50, who buys the breads whenever she visits Taiwan.

She says: "I must have his famous Taiwan longan with red wine bread and the Taiwan Litchi Rose. I also enjoy his European-style bread. I'm more than happy to queue for the bread in Taiwan and I'll be happy to do the same here. I just hope the standards are kept up."

Popular items at the bakery
TAIWAN LITCHI ROSE

Famously known as Wu Pao-chun's champion bread, it won first prize in 2010 at the Masters de la Boulangerie or Bakery Masters in Paris - for individual competitors - and was instrumental in catapulting him to fame. He won the title of Master Baker and his Taiwan Litchi Rose bread was praised by the judges as the "best European-style bread". The dough requires at least 15 hours to rise and the black-leaf lychee fruit and organic rose petals from Puli, central Nantou County, are soaked in lychee wine overnight to release their fragrance.
GERMAN PUDDING
Looking more like quiche than bread, the "German pudding" has a soft filling - made with cream, butter, fresh milk and eggs - and comes in a crispy crust.
SALZBURG
This French-style bread is filled with bacon, gouda cheese and black pepper. It is crispy on the outside and soft inside.
TAIWAN LONGAN WITH RED WINE

Created for the French baking competition Coupe Louis Lesaffre in 2008, it was awarded second prize. The competition also pre-selects candidates to compete on a global level. Longans from Dongshan, Tainan, are smoked for six days and mixed with red wine, plumule (the first shoot that grows from the seed of a plant) powder, French red wine and walnuts from California.
BROWN SUGAR MOCHI

This is from the chain's selection of Japanese-style bread. Milk, bread flour, butter and egg yolks are kneaded to make a pliable dough. Brown sugar mochi is then wrapped in the dough, resulting in a fragrant bun.
HOSHINO SALTY BREAD

Dry yeast is fermented overnight, then kneaded into the dough with powdered rye and French bread flour and shaped into loaves. This whole process takes at least three days to complete and is key in bringing out the unique flavour of the yeast.
PHOTOS: WU PAO CHUN
